name: UniversalIdType
title: universalIdType
description: HL7-defined code system of types of UID (Universal Identifiers).   Used in HL7 Version 2.x messaging HD and EI datatypes.
purpose: Underlying Master Code System for V2 table 0301 (Universal ID Type)
copyright: Copyright HL7. Licensed under creative commons public domain

property.description: Version of HL7 in which the code was deprecated

concept.display: College of American Pathologist Accreditation Number
concept.definition: Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a "CAP" assigned number (for labs)

property.valueString: Use to identify assigning authority IDs, when an OID is not available.

concept.definition: Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a "CLIA" assigned number (for labs)

property.valueString: Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIA” assigned number (for labs)

concept.definition: Clinical laboratory Improvement Program. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a "CLIP" assigned number (for labs).Â  Used by US Department of Defense.

property.valueString: Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIP” assigned number (for labs).  Used by US Department of Defense.

concept.definition: An Internet host name, in accordance with RFC 1035; or an IP address. Either in ASCII or as integers, with periods between components ("dotted" notation).

property.valueString: An Internet host name, in accordance with RFC 1035; or an IP address. Either in ASCII or as integers, with periods between components (“dotted” notation).

concept.definition: IEEE 64-bit Extended Unique Identifier is comprised of a  24-bit company identifier and a 40-bit instance identifier.  The value shall be formatted as 16 ASCII HEX digits, for example, “AABBCC1122334455”.  The 24-bit company identifier, formally known as Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI-24), is guaranteed to be globally unique.  The 40-bit extensions are assigned by manufacturers.  This identifier is often used in equipment interfaces (e.g., “MAC” address format for IPv4 & IPv6).  [See http://standards.ieee.org/regauth/oui/tutorials/EUI64.html for a detailed explanation of the format.]

property.valueString: IEEE 64-bit Extended Unique Identifier is comprised of a  24-bit company identifier and a 40-bit instance identifier.  The value shall be formatted as 16 ASCII HEX digits, for example, “AABBCC1122334455”.  The 24-bit company identifier, formally known as Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI-24), is guaranteed to be globally unique.  The 40-bit extensions are assigned by manufacturers.  This identifier is often used in equipment interfaces (e.g., “MAC” address format for IPv4 & IPv6).  [See http://standards.ieee.org/regauth/oui/tutorials/EUI64.htmlfor a detailed explanation of the format.]OUI-24 values are administered by the IEEE Registration Authority.
OUI-24 values are administered by the IEEE Registration Authority.
Same as UUID. Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; use UUID instead
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; use UUID instead

concept.definition: The CEN Healthcare Coding Scheme Designator

property.valueString: The CEN Healthcare Coding Scheme Designator. Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; does not identify Assigning Authorities
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; does not identify Assigning Authorities
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; HL7 assigns ISO OIDs for Assigning Authorities
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; HL7 assigns ISO OIDs for Assigning Authorities

concept.definition: An International Standards Organization Object Identifier (OID), in accordance with ISO/IEC 8824.  Formatted as decimal digits separated by periods; recommended limit of 64 characters

property.valueString: An International Standards Organization Object Identifier (OID), in accordance with ISO/IEC 8824.  Formatted as decimal digits separated by periods; recommended limit of 64 characters

concept.definition: These are reserved for locally defined coding schemes.

concept.definition: Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a "NPI" assigned number (lab, any medical provider, can be a person or an organization)

property.valueString: Use to identify assigning authority IDs, when an OID is not available.  Especially important in the CNN datatype. Namespace maintained and published in the US.

concept.definition:
Usually a base64 encoded string of random bits.

Note: Random IDs are typically used for instance identifiers, rather than an identifier of an Assigning Authority that issues instance identifiers

property.valueString: Usually a base64 encoded string of random bits.Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; equivalent to a locally defined entity identifier scheme; use L. M, or N instead. Note: Random IDs are typically used for instance identifiers, rather than an identifier of an Assigning Authority that issues instance identifiers
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; equivalent to a locally defined entity identifier scheme; use L. M, or N instead.
Retained for backward compatibility only as of v2.7; equivalent to a locally defined entity identifier scheme; use L. M, or N instead.

concept.definition: The DCE Universal Unique Identifier, in accordance with RFC 4122. Recommended format is 32 hexadecimal digits separated by hyphens, in the digit grouping 8-4-4-4-12

property.valueString: The DCE Universal Unique Identifier, in accordance with RFC 4122. Recommended format is 32 hexadecimal digits separated by hyphens, in the digit grouping 8-4-4-4-12

concept.definition: An X.400 MHS identifier. Recommended format is in accordance with RFC 1649

property.valueString: Recommended format is in accordance with RFC 1649
